G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the acts complained of occurred in Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant failed to check his mirror or ensure the lane was clear prior to opening the door, in violation of his duty of reasonable care and of G.L. c. 90, § 14, which prohibits opening a vehicle door unless it is reasonably safe to do so.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every motorist owes a duty of reasonable care toward all other users of public ways, including bicyclists.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a property owner/general contractor’s potential liability for injuries from a scaffolding collapse and focuses on negligence elements such as duty, control, and causation in that context. It does not discuss motorists, public ways, or the scope of a motorist’s duty to bicyclists or other road users. Because the case never addresses duties of drivers on public ways, it does not support the stated proposition about motorists owing reasonable care to all users, including bicyclists.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every motorist owes a duty of reasonable care toward all other users of public ways, including bicyclists.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the duties of landowners/possessors of land with respect to adjacent public highways and on voluntarily assumed duties; it does not discuss the general duty of care owed by motorists to other users of public ways, including bicyclists. The case concerns a drunk driver striking a pedestrian and whether an adjacent business owed a duty to alter a state highway, not the baseline negligence duty of motorists themselves. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the stated proposition about motorists’ duties to all users of public ways.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. ... It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. ... Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.

Gorey v. Guarente, 303 Mass. 569 (1939).proposition: Defendant breached his duty of care by failing to (a) look for oncoming bicyclists before opening his door; (b) maintain proper attention while parked; and (c) ensure that his actions would not endanger others.
Gorey v. Guarente, 303 Mass. 569 (1939).support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts probate/trust construction case dealing with interpretation of a trust instrument and the distribution of a trust fund upon the settlor’s death. It does not involve negligence, motor vehicles, bicycles, duties of care, or any facts about opening car doors or looking for oncoming bicyclists. Therefore it provides no authority for the claimed duty-of-care proposition and appears to be a miscitation or entirely inapposite authority.
Gorey v. Guarente, 303 Mass. 569 (1939).relevant_excerpt: This is a petition filed in the Probate Court, by the trustees under a written declaration of trust of Winifred R. Guarente, for instructions as to whom and in what proportions they should pay the principal of the trust fund and the income accruing thereon. ... The important question is to determine the effect to be given to the instrument executed by the settlor and trustee on June 20, 1923. The intent of the creator of a trust is the controlling consideration in determining what rights were created by the trust instrument...

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts common law.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This is a dissenting opinion focused on proximate cause, not on whether the defendants’ conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts common law. The dissent expressly accepts that there was evidence of negligence (e.g., inadequate locking system) but concludes that plaintiff failed to prove causation; it therefore does not establish or affirm the proposition that the defendant’s conduct is negligent, and in any event is not the controlling holding of the case.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The next inquiry is whether, if the assailant was a lawful visitor, the jury could have found that he gained entrance to the plaintiff’s room due to the defendants’ negligence. I agree that the jury could have found that the system for locking the room door was inadequate due to the defendants’ negligence, but I do not agree that the jury could have found that entry into the room was gained by disengaging a lock.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts common law.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The case does not hold that the defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence as a matter of law; it holds only that the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care and therefore that the negligence claim may proceed to a jury. The court expressly leaves to the jury whether Kask breached that duty and whether her conduct was negligent. Thus, the opinion supports the existence of a duty under Massachusetts common law in these circumstances, not a definitive finding of negligence.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access... We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Defendant’s violation of G.L. c. 90, § 14 and related safety statutes constitutes evidence of negligence per se.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The court explicitly rejects negligence per se for violations of G.L. c. 138, § 69 and, by extension, similar safety statutes. It reiterates the Massachusetts rule that statutory violation is only ‘some evidence’ of negligence and does not itself establish a breach of duty. Thus, the opinion is direct authority against the claimed proposition that such statutory violations constitute negligence per se.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent.”

Guinan v. Boston Elevated Ry., 267 Mass..raw_text: Guinan v. Boston Elevated Ry., 267 Mass. 526 (1929)
Guinan v. Boston Elevated Ry., 267 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s violation of G.L. c. 90, § 14 and related safety statutes constitutes evidence of negligence per se.
Guinan v. Boston Elevated Ry., 267 Mass..case_name: Guinan v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.
Guinan v. Boston Elevated Ry., 267 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion does not address G.L. c. 90, § 14 or any related safety statutes, nor does it discuss negligence per se or statutory violations as evidence of negligence. The case is narrowly focused on an evidentiary issue: the trial judge’s discretion in excluding expert testimony about the cause of a flash of flame. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the proposition that violation of G.L. c. 90, § 14 constitutes evidence of negligence per se.
Guinan v. Boston Elevated Ry., 267 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The rule is well established that whether a person called as an expert has the necessary qualifications to testify is a preliminary question to be decided by the trial judge; and his decision is conclusive, unless it appears on the evidence to have been erroneous as matter of law. Perkins v. Stickney, 132 Mass. 217, 218. White v. McPherson, 183 Mass. 533, 534. Old Silver Beach Corp. v. Falmouth, 266 Mass. 224, 226.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf holds that the defendant’s conduct was not negligent at all with respect to Mrs. Palsgraf because her injury was outside the zone of foreseeable risk; therefore there was no duty to her and no actionable negligence. Cardozo explicitly treats the causation/proximate cause question as “foreign to the case” once he concludes there was no duty and thus no tort. The opinion is thus authority against the proposition that plaintiff’s injuries were the direct and proximate result of defendant’s negligence in this factual scenario.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The conduct of the defendant’s guard, if a wrong in its relation to the holder of the package, was not a wrong in its relation to the plaintiff, standing far away. Relatively to her it was not negligence at all… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us. The question of liability is always anterior to the question of the measure of the consequences that go with liability. If there is no tort to be redressed, there is no occasion to consider what damage might be recovered if there were a finding of a tort.”

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.proposition: As a further proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered physical injuries, pain and suffering, lost wages, medical expenses, and property damage to his bicycle.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns traditional negligence damages (physical injuries, pain and suffering, lost wages, medical expenses, and property damage to a bicycle). Payton v. Abbott Labs does not address such damages or proximate cause in a conventional accident context; instead it analyzes whether Massachusetts recognizes claims for negligent infliction of emotional distress without physical harm, wrongful life–type issues, prenatal injuries from drugs, and market-share liability. Nothing in the opinion discusses or affirms recovery for the specific categories of damages listed in the proposition, so it does not provide authority for that statement.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.relevant_excerpt: In summary, we hold that a plaintiff who alleges that she suffered injury in utero as a result of her mother's ingestion of a drug and that, but for the defendant's negligence, her mother would not have ingested that drug, has stated a claim upon which relief can be granted under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff was not contributorily negligent under G.L. c. 231, § 85; any alleged negligence on Plaintiff’s part was less than fifty percent and therefore does not bar recovery.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award prejudgment and postjudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
